entry.title: At Kenya college, Christian students foretold massacre
Christian students at Kenya's Garissa University foretold massacre
entry.summary: Students said Kenya's army eventually surrounded the campus but didn't overcome al-Shabab or end the killings.

entry.title: Gunman in Kenya university massacre ID'd as son of official
entry.summary: Hundreds of Kenyan youths have trained with Al Shabab and then returned to Kenya, posing a major security threat, according to former police chief Mathew Iteere.

entry.title: Gunman in Kenya University Massacre Was Government Official?s Son
entry.summary: Police waited seven hours before sending a special tactical unit into the college to fight the gunmen, Kenya's Daily Nation newspaper reported Sunday.

entry.title: UNMASKING THE GUNMEN Police: Kenya attacker was son of government official
entry.summary: To prevent an escalation of Islamic radicalization in Kenya, it is important that parents inform authorities if their children go missing or show tendencies of following violent extremism, said Njoka.

entry.title: Law graduate named as Kenya massacre killer as country mourns
entry.summary:
Kenyatta said people's "justified anger" should not lead to "the victimisation of anyone" -- a clear reference to Kenya's large Muslim and Somali minorities.

"Kenya is at war, and we must all stand together," said Naado, the deputy head of the Supreme Council of Kenya Muslims, saying the organisation was helping to raise money for the funerals of those killed and the medical costs of the scores of wounded.

entry.title: Kenya says government official's son was among gunmen in Garissa attack
entry.summary: "It...beggars belief that many of the failures that were witnessed during the Westgate siege - including the late deployment of specialised police - were repeated in Garissa," Kenya's biggest-selling said.

entry.title: Kenya says son of a government official was among gunmen in Garissa attack
entry.summary:
The Garissa assault has further strained the historically cordial relations between Kenya's Christian and Muslim communities, which have deteriorated due to frequent Islamist attacks on Christian priests and churches.

A dusk-to-dawn curfew is in force along Kenya's 700km border with Somalia and helicopters monitor its palm-fringed coast, popular with Western tourists and the scene of Islamist attacks in the past.

entry.title: Pope Francis prays for Kenya students, decries persecution
entry.summary: "May constant prayer rise up from all people of goodwill for those who lost their lives - I think in particular of the young people who were killed last Thursday at Garissa University College in Kenya - for all who have been kidnapped, and for those forced to abandon their homes and their dear ones."

entry.title: Kenya police: 1 gunman identified in attack that killed 148
entry.summary: Somalia's al-Shabab Islamic militants claimed responsibility for the attack on Garissa college Thursday saying it is retribution for Kenya deploying troops to Somalia to fight the extremist rebels.

entry.title: After Islamist attack, armed guards shield Kenyan churches
entry.summary: In Nairobi's Holy Family Basilica cathedral, nestled between the City Hall and Kenya's parliament, two uniformed police officers armed with AK-47 rifles manned the entrance gate.

entry.title: Kenya's religions unite in national mourning for massacre victims
entry.summary:
The massacre, Kenya's deadliest attack since the 1998 bombing of the US embassy in Nairobi, claimed the lives of 142 students, three police officers and three soldiers.

The militants vowed more attacks against Kenya, which invaded southern Somalia in 2011 and is now fighting alongside the African Union force battling the Shebab.

entry.title: Kenya mourns victims of student massacre with Easter prayers
entry.summary: The massacre was Kenya's deadliest attack since the 1998 bombing of the US embassy in Nairobi, and Kenyatta declared three days of national mourning beginning Sunday, calling for the killings to unite and not divide the country.

entry.title: Prayers, fear mark Easter services in Garissa, Kenya
Kenya's Easter prayers mark start of official mourning for university attacks
entry.summary: Earlier on Saturday, al-Shabaab warned of a "long, gruesome war" unless Kenya withdrew its troops from Somalia, and threatened "another bloodbath".

entry.title: Kenyatta says campus attackers 'embedded' in Kenya's Muslim community
entry.summary: In a message directed at Kenyans, the al Qaeda aligned group said the raid on Garissa was revenge for Kenya's military presence in Somalia and mistreatment of Muslims within Kenya.

entry.title: Militant group al-Shabab threatens more attacks on Kenya
Kenya university death toll seen rising; anger over security failures
entry.summary: Al Qaeda itself killed some 207 people when it blew up the U.S. embassy in Nairobi in 1998, an attack which remains the single biggest loss of life in Kenya since its independence from Britain in 1963.

entry.title: Kenyatta says campus attackers 'embedded' in Kenya's Muslim community
entry.summary: The timing of the attack was embarrassing for Kenyatta, who a day earlier had berated Britain and Australia for issuing travel warnings for Kenya due to security threats.

entry.title: Paraded in front of a crowd at a primary school: Gruesome pictures emerge of terrorists' bodies being put on display - after survivor of Kenya massacre is found alive after hiding for two days in a wardrobe
entry.summary: Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta said today that those behind the attack were 'deeply embedded' in Kenya, and called on Kenyan Muslims to help prevent radicalisation.

entry.title: Kenyatta says Garissa attackers 'embedded' in Kenya Muslim community
entry.summary:
Four attackers died at Garissa, but Kenya has not named them or announced their nationalities.

The attack at Garissa, which lies 120 miles from the Somali border, has put Kenya on high alert and spooked its Christian communities after reports the gunmen sought out Christian students while sparing some Muslims.

Kenyatta's comments will put more pressure on Kenya's Muslim community, who make up about 10 percent of the 44-million-strong population.

entry.title: Kenya burns 15 tonnes of ivory to deter elephant poachers
entry.summary:
Nairobi:Kenya has burned 15 tonnes of elephant tusks and rhino horns as part of efforts to curb poaching of the mammals in the East African country.

"This shows we are committed to save our elephants and we want the world to know that ivory belongs to the elephants," Paul Udoto, spokesman for the Kenya Wildlife Service, said at the ceremony.

Poachers killed 164 elephants in Kenya last year, compared with 302 in 2013 and 384 in 2012, while 53 rhinos were killed in 2014 compared with 59 and 30 in the previous two years, according to the Kenya Wildlife Service.

Kenya's President Uhuru Kenyatta, centre, looks on as 15 tonnes of ivory confiscated from smugglers and poachers is burnt in Nairobi National Park.

Kenya may have as much as 100 tonnes of contraband ivory in its stockpiles, according to Paula Kahumba, chief executive officer of WildlifeDirect, a Nairobi-based non-governmental conservation organisation.

"The ivory burned by Moi was mainly from internal poaching, but today we have tusks from elephants poached internally and those confiscated while in transit through Kenya," Mr Muya said.

entry.title: Three days of mourning as Kenya grapples with Garissa massacre
entry.summary:
Along Kenya's palm-fringed coastline, where several resort towns cater mainly for Western tourists, police have deployed armed officers in major public buildings.

"Officers are everywhere both on the ground and in the air. We have two helicopters that will be patrolling the entire coastal area," Robert Kitur, police chief for Kenya's Indian Ocean coast region, told Reuters.

Garissa Governor Nathif Jama said the region has a number of security "soft spots", including schools and hospitals, and asked for more boots on the ground in his county, which forms part of Kenya's porous 700km border with Somalia.

entry.title: Kenya: Extremists vow more attacks; president responds
entry.summary:
Kenya Defence Forces (KDF) soldiers arrive at a hospital to escort the bodies of the attackers to be put on public view, in Garissa, Kenya Saturday, April 4, 2015.

A woman covers her mouth after going in to view the bodies of the alleged attackers, having been encouraged to do so by security guards, at the hospital mortuary in Garissa, Kenya Saturday, April 4, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya's president vows harsh action against Somali rebels
entry.summary: Members of the public run to get a glimpse as authorities display the bodies of the alleged attackers before about 2,000 people in a large open area in central Garissa, Kenya Saturday, April 4, 2015.

entry.title: Somali extremists al-Shabab warn of more attacks in Kenya
entry.summary: Survivor of the killings at Garissa University College Cynthia Cheroitich, 19, who was found on Saturday two days after the attack, drinks some milk in a hospital ward in Garissa, Kenya Saturday, April 4, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya: Survivor found in school attack which killed 148
entry.summary: Relatives line up to view the bodies of their loved ones in Thursday's attack on a university, at Chiromo funeral home, Nairobi, Kenya, Saturday, April 4, 2015.

entry.title: Somali militants vow to turn Kenyan cities 'red with blood'
entry.summary: Along Kenya's palm-fringed coastline, police have put armed officers in major public buildings.

entry.title: Somali militants threaten more attacks against Kenya
entry.summary: The al Qaeda aligned group said the attack was retribution for Kenya's presence in Somalia and mistreatment of Muslims within Kenya.

entry.title: Somali militants threaten more bloody attacks against Kenya
entry.summary:
MOGADISHU (Reuters) - Somali militants on Saturday threatened to stage more bloody attacks on Kenya after the group's fighters killed nearly 150 people during an assault on a Kenyan university on Thursday.

In the message, directed at the Kenyan public, the group vowed a long and gruesome war, saying Kenya's cities will "run red with blood".

entry.title: Five arrested in connection with Kenya attack
entry.summary: Kenya's biggest-selling Daily Nation newspaper, citing sources, said the death toll would be significantly higher.

entry.title: Kenya mourns 148 dead in university attack by militants
entry.summary:
Somali President Hassan Sheikh Mohamud called for stronger collaboration between his country and Kenya to defeat al-Shabab.

A statement approved by all 15 council members paid tribute to Kenya's role in fighting "terrorism" - especially its role in the African Union's mission in Somalia against al-Shabab.

Obama, who is scheduled to visit Nairobi in July, "emphasized his support for the government and people of Kenya," according to a statement.

A day before the attack, Kenyatta dismissed that warning as well as an Australian one pertaining to Nairobi and Mombasa, saying: "Kenya is safe as any country in the world. The travel advisories being issued by our friends are not genuine."

entry.title: Grief turns to anger as details of Kenya university massacre emerge
entry.summary:
"I know firsthand the extraordinary resilience and fundamental decency of the people of Kenya. So I know that the people of Garissa and all of Kenya will grieve but their determination to achieve a better and more secure future will not be deterred," Mr Obama said.

However, diplomats and analysts say the move effectively concedes the government cannot control those areas, widely seen as Kenya's soft underbelly.

entry.title: Pope decries killing of Christians
entry.summary: He too mentioned the Kenya attack, as well as the beheading of 22 Egyptian Coptic Christians by Islamic State (IS) militants in Libya in February.

entry.title: Pope decries persecution of Christians, including in Kenya
entry.summary: In their attack on the university in Kenya on Thursday, al Shabaab militants initially killed indiscriminately but later freed some Muslims and targeted Christian students during a siege that lasted about 15 hours..

entry.title: Kenya mourns 148 dead in university attack by militants
entry.summary: Kenyan Muslims demonstrate against Thursday's attack and in solidarity with non-Muslims who were targeted, on a street in Garissa, Kenya Friday, April 3, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya attack survivor says gunmen had scouted the campus
entry.summary: A mother, second right, grieves after discovering her son was amongst those killed, as she leaves a center set up for relatives and survivors in Garissa, Kenya, Friday, April 3, 2015.

entry.title: Shock, defiance in Kenya after Shebab massacre 148 at university
entry.summary: The day-long siege of Garissa University in which 148 people, mostly students, were killed was Kenya's deadliest attack since the 1998 bombing of the US embassy in Nairobi, and the bloodiest ever by the Al-Qaeda-affiliated militants.

entry.title: Kenya attack survivor says gunmen had scouted the campus
entry.summary:
A woman gestures after she viewed the body of a relative killed in Thursday's attack on a university, at Chiromo funeral home, Nairobi, Kenya, Friday, April 3, 2015.

Members of Kenya Defense Forces stand guard at the Garissa University College in Garissa, northeastern Kenya, Friday, April 3, 2015.

A victim of Thursday's university attack is assisted to a plane by medical staff prior to being airlifted to Nairobi, at the Garissa military airstrip, Garissa, Kenya, Friday, April 3, 2015.

entry.title: Kenya attack survivor says gunmen had scouted the campus
entry.summary: The attack at Garissa University College happened six days after Britain advised "against all but essential travel" to parts of Kenya, including Garissa.

entry.title: Kenya attack survivor says gunmen had scouted the campus
entry.summary: Al-Shabab gunmen rampaged through a university in northeastern Kenya at dawn Thursday, killing scores of people in the group's deadliest attack in the East African country.

entry.title: Pope condemns Kenya school attack as 'senseless brutality'
Survivor of Deadly Kenya University Attack Says Gunmen Had Scouted Campus
entry.summary: In Nairobi, Kenya's capital, family members were lining up at a morgue where about 20 bodies had already been airlifted from Garissa, victims of the worst attack in Kenya since the 1998 bombing of the U.S. Embassy by al-Qaida which killed more than 200 people.

entry.title: Kenya attack survivor says gunmen had scouted the campus
Kenya attack survivor says gunmen scouted campus, targeted Christians
entry.summary: The Islamic extremists who slaughtered 147 people at a college in northeast Kenya as they shouted "God is great" appeared to have planned extensively, even targeting a site where Christians had gone to pray, survivors said Friday.

entry.title: Kenya college attack survivor hid among dead
entry.summary:
In Nairobi, Kenya's capital, family members were lining up at a morgue where about 20 bodies had already been airlifted from Garissa.

The group has vowed to retaliate against Kenya for sending troops to Somalia in 2011 to fight the militants staging cross-border attacks and kidnappings.

entry.title: Al-Shabab militants kill 147 at university in Kenya
entry.summary: The al-Qaida-linked group has been blamed for a series of attacks in Kenya, including the siege at the Westgate Mall in Nairobi in 2013 that killed 67 people, as well as other violence in the north.

entry.title: The Latest: UN secretary-general condemns attack in Kenya
entry.summary: Kenya's national disaster operations center and the interior minister say the attack by al-Shabab gunmen on a college campus has claimed 147 lives, besides four attackers who also died.

entry.title: 147 dead as al-Shabab gunmen attack Garissa University: Kenya interior minister
entry.summary: President Uhuru Kenyatta says the government has deployed security forces try to end a hostage situation more than nine hours since al-Shabab gunmen attacked a college in northeast Kenya.

entry.title: The Latest: Officials: 147 die in Kenya attack
entry.summary:
Kenyan security officials at the scene of an attack by Islamic extremists on a college in northeast Kenya say the security operation to free hostages is over and that the death toll may be as high as around 150.

The man whom Kenyan police say was a possible mastermind of the attack on a college in northeast Kenya is currently in charge of al-Shabab's external operations against Kenya, according to Kenya's intelligence service.

entry.title: Al-Shabaab Kenya attack: death toll rises to 147 – live updates
entry.summary: Kenyan Interior Minister Joseph Nkaissery says that more than 70 people have been killed in an attack by Somali-based Islamic extremists on a college in northeast Kenya.

entry.title: The Latest: Death toll more than 70 in Kenya college attack
entry.summary:
Kenyan police have offered a $220,000 bounty for Mohammed Mohamud, also known as Dulyadin alias Gamadhere whom they believe is the mastermind of the attack on a college in Garissa, in northeast Kenya.

Michael Bwana, a 20-year-old student who managed to flee from the al-Shabab attack on a college in Kenya, said he and other survivors have been trying to call their trapped friends but their phones are switched off.

entry.title: Gunmen kill more than 70 at university in Kenya
entry.summary: Police identified a possible mastermind of the attack as Mohammed Mohamud, who is alleged to lead al-Shabab's cross-border raids into Kenya, and they posted a $220,000 bounty for him.

entry.title: Kenya Officials: Security Op Over, 4 Attackers Killed, Death Toll May Be High as About 150
Over 70 dead as masked gunmen attack Garissa University: Kenya interior minister
entry.summary: Also known by the names Dulyadin and Gamadhere, he was a teacher at an Islamic religious school, or madrassa, and claimed responsibility for a bus attack in Makka, Kenya, in November that killed 28 people.

entry.title: ‘If you were Christian, you were shot’: Death toll climbs to 70 in Kenya attack
entry.summary: In his speech to the country, he said he had directed the police chief to fast-track the training of 10,000 police recruits because Kenya has "suffered unnecessarily due to shortage of security personnel."

entry.title: Gunmen attack university in northeastern Kenya
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - Gunmen attacked a college campus in northeast Kenya early Thursday, opening fire in dormitories and killing at least 15 people and wounding 29 others, witnesses said.

entry.title: Gunmen attack university in northeastern Kenya
entry.summary: Abass Gulett, head of the Red Cross in Kenya, said fighting was ongoing as the security forces try to retake some university blocks from the gunmen.

entry.title: Gunmen attack university in northeastern Kenya
entry.summary:
Some students without their shirts of the Garissa University College get out of a house where they seek refuge after escaping from an attack by gunmen in Garissa, Kenya, Thursday, April 2, 2015.

Kenya's National Disaster Operations Center said 29 people wounded during the attack have been admitted to a local hospital, four of them in critical condition.

entry.title: Kenya says 29 people wounded in attack on university, most with gunshot wounds
Masked gunmen storm university in Kenya
entry.summary: NAIROBI, Kenya -- Gunmen attacked Garissa University College early Thursday, shooting indiscriminately in campus hostels, killing at least two people and wounding four others, police said.

entry.title: Gunmen attack university in eastern Kenya, 2 dead: Police
entry.summary: Police and military surrounded the buildings and were trying to secure the area in eastern Kenya, police officer Musa Yego said.

entry.title: Gunmen attack Kenya university in 'fierce shootout'
entry.summary: Kenya's National Police Service said in a written statement that armed attackers forced their way onto the campus by shooting at guards, triggering a "fierce shootout" with police guarding student hostels.

entry.title: Masked gunmen storm Kenya university
entry.summary: Heavy gunfire and explosions were heard and the stand-off was ongoing at the Garissa University College, the Kenya's Daily Nation newspaper and Capital FM radio station said.

entry.title: Police: Heavy gunfire reported as masked gunmen attack Garrisa university in Kenya's northeast
Masked gunmen storm uni campus
entry.summary: A POLICE official says masked gunmen have stormed a university campus in Garissa Town in eastern Kenya.

entry.title: Masked gunmen storm Kenya college campus, local media says
entry.summary: Al-Qaeda-linked al-Shabaab has vowed to punish Kenya for sending troops into Somalia alongside African Union peacekeepers to fight the group.

entry.title: Gunmen storm Kenyan college campus in Garissa: media
entry.summary: Somali Islamist militant group al Shabaab has carried out several attacks in Garissa and across Kenya in the past, including the 2013 attack on an upscale shopping mall in the capital Nairobi.

entry.title: Police: Gunmen attack university in eastern Kenya
entry.summary: Kenya's northern and eastern regions, which border Somalia, have been most affected by attacks blamed on al-Qaida-linked al-Shabab Islamists from Somalia.

entry.title: Police: Masked gunmen attack university in Kenya
Kenya Trip Will Fire Up Obama's Critics
entry.summary: His father, Barack Obama Sr., was from Kenya.

entry.title: Obama to make first visit to Kenya as president
entry.summary:
During a trip to other African countries last year, he said he was likely to visit Kenya before leaving the White House.

The president's father came to the United States from Kenya for school and returned to his home country after his son's birth.

The elder Obama died more than 30 years ago, though the president has other family still living in Kenya.

entry.title: Obama to make first visit to Kenya as president
entry.summary:
The White House says Obama will visit Kenya in July for the Global Entrepreneurship Summit, which brings together business leaders, international organizations and governments.

Obama visited Kenya as a U.S. senator, but never as president.

entry.title: Obama to make first visit to Kenya as president
Kenya's president apologizes for government's past wrongs
entry.summary: The government-funded report found that Kenya's second and third presidents, Daniel Arap Moi and Mwai Kibaki, headed governments that were responsible for massacres, economic crimes and grand corruption, among other violations.

entry.title: Kenya's president apologizes for government's past wrongs
entry.summary:
Kenya's Truth Justice and Reconciliation Commission report had recommended that the president apologize to the public within six month after receiving it.

Kenya's state security agencies, particularly the police and army, have been the main perpetrators of human rights violations, including massacres, enforced disappearances, torture and sexual violence, the report said.

entry.title: Kenya's president apologizes for past wrongs by his government and previous regimes
entry.summary: The report names the president and his deputy as being among those suspected of planning and financing Kenya's 2007-08 postelection violence in which more than 1,000 people died.

entry.title: 'No blacks' Chinese restaurant shut down in Kenya
entry.summary: Reports said the restaurant's Chinese owners and managers had also been summoned by Kenya's immigration authorities.

entry.title: Pentagon: Drone killed mastermind of Kenya mall attack
Al-Shabab claim responsibility for 4 dead in Kenya
entry.summary:
Kenya's northern and eastern region border Somalia and a significant number of inhabitants there are Kenyan-Somalis.

Police statistics show that 312 people have been killed in al-Shabab attacks in Kenya from 2012 to 2014.

entry.title: Al-Shabab claim attack which killed 4 people, wounded 3 northern Kenya
entry.summary:
"The attack is part of a series of attacks targeting the Northern Frontier District region under Kenya's occupation," said al-Shabab's radio Andulus."The Mujahideen forces who carried out the attack safely returned to base."

Al-Shabab has been attacking Kenya since Kenyan troops were deployed to Somalia in Oct 2011 to fight the militants.

entry.title: New Shebab attack in northeast Kenya kills four
entry.summary: The attack is the fourth in five days in Kenya's remote and increasingly lawless northeast, which borders war-torn Somalia.

entry.title: Islamic extremist group al-Shabab suspected in northern Kenya attack that kills 1, wounds 3
entry.summary: Adan Duale, a Kenyan Somali who is majority leader in parliament, was quoted on the BBC Somali Service on Saturday telling al-Shabab to leave Kenya alone.

entry.title: Al-Shabab suspected in Kenya attack that kills 1, wounds 3
entry.summary:
"If you wish to, we shall send you elders, religious leaders and politicians. We shall come, tell us your whereabouts. Leave Kenya alone," Duale said in a statement that many in Kenya interpreted as a call for negotiations with al-Shabab.

But Duale said Sunday on his Twitter account that Kenya will never negotiate with "terrorists."

Kenya has experienced a string of attacks since it sent troops into Somalia in October 2011.

entry.title: Death toll four in attack on Kenya governor convoy, says official
entry.summary: Al Shabaab has launched many attacks inside Kenya, saying it will continue until Kenyan forces are withdrawn from Somalia, where they are fighting alongside other African forces against the Islamist group.

entry.title: Kenya Police: 3 people killed in attack on governors convoy
entry.summary: Hundreds of teachers in parts of northern Kenya that borders Somalia have refused to return to work, fearing attacks by the Islamic extremists despite government reassurance of increased security.

entry.title: Kenya Police: 3 people killed in attack on governors convoy
entry.summary: Al-Shabab, an Islamic extremist group, has vowed to inflict violent attacks on Kenya because it has contributed troops to the African Union force supporting the western-backed government in Somalia.

entry.title: Kenya: Businessmen, ex-officials charged for fraud and abuse of office
entry.summary: Al-Shabab extremists from Somalia have carried out 129 attacks in Kenya since Oct. 2011 saying its retribution for the Kenyan troop presence in Somalia.

entry.title: Kenya: Businessmen, ex-officials charged for fraud
Kenya burns 15 tonnes of ivory worth ?19.4m - video
entry.summary: The ivory, with a black market value of $30m ( 19.4m), is the largest consignment to be destroyed in Kenya.

entry.title: Kenya torches 15 tonnes of illegal ivory in anti-poaching fight
entry.summary:
Kenya has burnt 15 tonnes of ivory and promised to destroy all of its stockpile this year in the latest step in its campaign against elephant poaching.

Kenya has imposed longer jail terms and bigger fines for wildlife poaching and trafficking, saying poaching is harming tourism, a major earner of foreign exchange.

entry.title: Kenya burns 15 tonnes of ivory in anti-poaching fight
entry.summary: "As part of Kenya's continued policy to put ivory beyond economic use ... I will today burn 15 tonnes of ivory at this historic site in Nairobi National Park," President Uhuru Kenyatta said during a ceremony at the park.

entry.title: Kenya destroy 15 tons of ivory taken from poachers
entry.summary:
Hamilton said Kenya has a long way to go before it can be clear of the poaching menace.

"We would like to tell the world to stop the trade in ivory because it is destroying our economy, our heritage, our environment," said Paul Udoto, a spokesman for the Kenya Wildlife Service.

entry.title: Kenya destroy 15 tons of ivory taken from poachers
entry.summary:
NAIROBI, Kenya (AP) - Kenya's president set fire to 15 tons of elephant tusks during World Wildlife Day Tuesday to discourage poaching and trade in ivory.

The years 2011, 2012 and 2013 witnessed the highest levels of poaching since a poaching crisis in the 1980s, Kenya's Wildlife Service has said.

entry.title: Kenya destroy 15 tons of ivory taken from poachers
